column1: ourspanishblog 154242894271 "2016-12-09 11:35:47 GMT" http://ourspanishblog.tumblr.com/post/154242894271/words-in-spanish-that-look-very-similar-to-english "Words in Spanish that look very similar to English words but have different meanings! (:colegio ≠ college → colegio = (private) school- Voy al colegio todos los días. = I go to school every day.- ¿Cómo te fue hoy en el colegio? = How was school today?college = universidad; facultad- Estudié derecho en la universidad. = I studied law at college.- Estudio en la facultad de arte. = I study at Art College.embarazada ≠ embarrassed → embarazada = pregnant- Mi hermana está embarazada. = My sister is pregnant. embarrassed = avergonzado/a(s)- No tienes que sentirte avergonzado. = You don’t have to feel embarrassed.- Lo siento
column3: I’m so embarrassed.éxito ≠ exit → éxito = success- El proyecto fue todo un éxito. = The project was such a success. - The deseo mucho éxito. = I wish you a lot of success.exit = salida- La salida es por allá. = The exit is over there.- Disculpe
column5: where is the exit?fábrica ≠ fabric → fábrica = factory- Charlie y la fábrica de chocolate. = Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.- Mi padre trabaja en una fábrica. = My father works in a factory. fabric = tela- Es sólo un pedazo de tela. = It’s just a piece of fabric. - No me gusta la tela de este vestido. = I don’t like this dress fabric.grabar ≠ to grab → grabar = to record- Esta llamada será grabada. = This call will be recorded.- Voy a grabar un video con mis amigos. = I’ll record a video with my friends.to grab = agarrar
column6: coger (España)- Agarra todas las frutas que quieras. = Grab all the fruits you want.- Me agarró de la mano. = She/He grabbed my hand.grosería ≠ grocery → grosería = rudeness
column7: swear word- No voy a tolerar tus groserías. = I won’t tolerate your rudeness(coarseness)- No digas groserías. = Don’t swear (Don’t say bad words)grocery = abarrotes
column8: despensa- Voy a la tienda de abarrotes / la tiendita. = I’m going to the grocery store.- Tengo que comprar la despensa. = I’ve to buy groceries. introducir ≠ introduce → introducir = to insert
column10: to introduce (sth)- Introduce la llave en la cerradura. = Insert the key into the lock.- La empresa introdujo dos nuevos productos. = The company introduced two new products. introduce (someone) = presentar(se)- Madre
column11: te presento a mi novia Laura. = Mother
column12: here’s my girlfriend Laura (I introduce you to my girlfriend Laura.)-¿Puedes presentarte a la clase? = Can you introduce yourself to the class?letra ≠ letter (send a letter) → letra = letter (writing
column13: alphabet)- ¿Cuántas letras tiene la palabra “casa”? = How many letters does the word “casa” have?- ¿Qué letra es ésta? = What’s this letter?letter (send) = carta- Te escribí una carta con mucho cariño. = I wrote you a letter with a lot of love(affection).- Quiero enviar una carta a mi padre. = I want to send a letter to my father.librería ≠ library → librería = book store- Voy a comprar libros a la librería. = I’m going to buy books at the book store.- ¿Dónde hay una librería por aquí? = Where’s a book store around here?library = biblioteca- Renté este libro de la biblioteca. = I rented this book from the library.- Ella pasa horas leyendo en la biblioteca. = She spends hours reading at the library.molestar ≠ to molest → molestar = to bother
column15: annoy- Deja de molestarme. = Stop bothering me. - Cuando estoy estudiando cualquier ruido me molesta. = When I’m studying every noise annoys me.to molest = abusar/acosar sexualmente- Ese hombre trató de abusar sexualmente de esa chica. = That man tried to molest that girl.realizar ≠ to  realize → realizar = to perform
column16: to achieve- El científico realizó un experimento en su laboratorio. = The scientist performed an experiment in his laboratory.- Él realizó su sueño de ser actor. = He achieved his dream of becoming an actor.to realize = darse cuenta- Por fin te diste cuenta. = You finally realized (found out).- Me di cuenta de que me estaba mintiendo. = I found out he was lying to me.soportar ≠ to support → soportar = to bear
column18: to put up with- Ya no lo soporto. = I can’t stand it (bear it) any more.- Esta silla puede soportar mucho peso. = This chair can bear a lot of weight.to support = apoyar- Las empresas debería apoyar este proyecto. = Companies should support this project.- Yo apoyo económicamente a mi familia. = I economically support my family." column1: ourspanishblog 148562410471 "2016-08-06 23:02:31 GMT" http://ourspanishblog.tumblr.com/post/148562410471/self-criticism-when-learning-spanish-or-any-other "¡Hola a todos! Hello everyone!First of all I want to apologize because I haven’t post much recently. I’ll find the time! I just need to organize better ^^Anyway
column2: what I wanted to tell you today:I’ve been teaching Spanish to foreigners for the past month. I had class with very beginners to advanced students. And I’ve noticed something
column3: many times students have this idea that they’re not trying good enough
column4: or they’re not learning as fast as they’re supposed to do
column5: or their grammar is a mess
column6: etc. I’ve had students that have a wide vocabulary and their grammar is almost perfect
column7: so I tell them! “wow! your Spanish is excellent
column9: and then they tell me things like “oh! thank you but… I don’t think that’s true” or “thank you
column11: I don’t believe it”. At that moment
column13: I wish they were me looking at them speaking flawless Spanish. So that’s been a lesson to me
column14: too. I’m also learning a language: Korean
column15: and when a teacher tells me that I have a good vocabulary or my accent is good
column16: I don’t want to believe them. But then I remember myself telling that to my students
column17: and that I get so powerless because I want them to see what I see
column18: a very good student who is doing excellent
column19: and that I can see their effort and improvement. So next time someone tells you that you’re doing good in your Spanish learning process
column20: and you don’t really believe it… do it! Just believe them! Seriously
column22: you might not be speaking like a native right now
column23: but you only get there with practice
column27: your first conversations might not be the best
column28: but people usually are very kind and want to help. The more effort you put in learning a language
column30: people are more likely to help. If you’re a beginner and you don’t feel confident to start speaking right now
column31: and you’re waiting for the day you have more vocabulary and grammar
column33: that day won’t come. Because you will always want to have more vocabulary and more grammar
column34: and you will never feel confident enough to speak because there will always be something to learn
column38: stop thinking about the day you have perfect Spanish. Even native Spanish speakers make mistakes. Enjoy your learning process
column39: have fun! Make mistakes and learn from them
column45: meet people. That’s what is going to give you confidence to speak a language
column46: not grammar. I believe in you. ♡" True text

column1: ourspanishblog 142933459476 "2016-04-17 04:43:46 GMT" http://ourspanishblog.tumblr.com/post/142933459476/dónde-a-en-de "Today we are going to see the Question Word “dónde” plus prepositions.Prepositions:a (to)en (in
column4: of)A + dóndeWe use [a + donde] when the person is going from one place to another.¿A dónde vas? (Where are you going?)¿A dónde vas a viajar? (Where are you going to travel?)¿A dónde llevas esas cajas? (Where are you taking those boxes?)Think about the answer
column5: if the answer uses a before the place where we are going
column6: then the question should have a too. Possible answers to the questions above:Voy a la escuela. (I’m going to school)Voy a viajar a Colombia. (I’m going to travel to Colombia)Llevo estas cajas a la oficina. (I take this boxes to the office)En + dóndeWe use [en + dónde] when we are staying in one place
column7: and probably doing something.¿En dónde estás? (Where are you?)¿En dónde trabajas? (Where do you work?)¿En dónde te gusta estudiar? (Where do you like to study?)¿En dónde están mis gafas? (Where are my glasses?)*With this kind of questions you can omit “en”Also
column9: if the answer has en before the place
column10: then the question should have en
column11: too. Possible answers to the questions above:Estoy en el parque. (I’m in the park)Trabajo en una universidad. (I work at a university)Me gusta estudiar en la biblioteca. (I like to study in the library)Tus gafas están en la mesa. (Your glasses are on the table)De + dóndeWe use [de + dónde] when we want to ask about the origin or place where someone or something come from.¿De dónde eres? (Where are you from?)¿De dónde son los churros? (Where are churros from?)¿De dónde sacaste eso? (Where did you get that from?)As in previous examples
column12: think about the answer of these questions. If the answer has de before the place
column13: then the question should have de
